body: I understand it would help packagers, but I am not sure we want to do this.  We often ship very particular dev branches of these projects and the notebook won't work with regular released versions.  Currently this is the case with jqueryui and ace, but has also been the case in the past with code mirror.  Also, the minified ones greatly help the loading speed of the notebook, shipping the unminified forms would slow things down for everyone.

I don't mean using the unminified script at runtime. Its perfectly fine to use the minified versions there.
Only have them lying around in the source tree so one can see what the minified version actually does.

This would probably also aid third party debugging efforts as they can then more easily use tools that can map between minified and unminified at runtime.

Are you saying you would ship both the minified and unminified versions.  There is another issue - for many of these projects the unminified version is _many_ files.  IOW, the minified version is constructed by concatenating a bunch of files together and then minifying the result.  How would you handle that?

I don't see an issue with many sources compared to one.
every compresser worth its bytes can handle both, e.g. yui-compressor.

Yes, but I guess I am wondering if you would ship the many source files with ipython as well as the final minified version?  If so, I guess I am not convinced that this is worth it.  What do @fperez, @takluyver and @minrk think?

One approach would be to have the unminified version in the source tree, and minify it for the release tarballs. But that seems like a large part of our source tree would be javascript libraries that we hardly ever touch.

Once the javascript we're depending on is regular released versions, maybe we should remove it from the source tree, and have setup.py put it in place as part of the build. Then it could easily be configured to have minified or unminified versions.

I don't think it makes sense to ship unminified versions in the tarballs that end users download from PyPI, but perhaps it makes sense to have them in 'packager tarballs'. We already have separate tarballs on github without the built docs.

The proposal to put unminified versions in the source tree but minified it for the release would make things extremely difficult.  This is because the unminified versions consist of multiple files that need to be included in the HTML files in a completely different manner than the minified version.  I really don't like the idea of having to deal with all those file.

Also, I don't think we will settle into always using released versions of the JS libraries for a long time.

Finally, I don't like the idea of IPython's build process depending on having JS minimizer libraries installed.

I guess I don't see the issue with packagers just using the JS libraries that IPython ships.  Javascript libraries we quite different than Python libraries in that can't be imported from different locations in the file system.  When the IPython notebook runs, those libraries have to be in IPython's source tree in the right place.  If the packagers don't include the JS libraries in the IPython package, but have to copy them into place later, what is saved?  Am I missing something?

I'm not asking for you to minify the sources at buildtime. Only provide unminified sources of what you are using.
When you minify the source and commit it to git, just commit the unminified along with it.Is that really so much more work?
Packagers can then decide to minify it at buildtime, use a already packaged version or to use the provided minified version.

having minified sources is equivalent to having binary blobs, one has no idea whats in it nor can you modify it to your needs.
this violates e.g. debians free software guidlines.

On Sun, Jan 15, 2012 at 2:56 PM, Julian Taylor
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> having minified sources is equivalent to having binary blobs, one have no idea whats in nor can you modify it to your needs.
> this violates e.g. debians free software guidlines.

Mmh, this is a tricky one.  On the one hand, we want to keep the
developer's workflow as simple as possible, as well as the size of the
download repos.  On the other, we don't want to get kicked out of
debian/ubuntu (and possibly fedora, I don't know if they have the same
policy), and we really appreciate the packaging work you do.

Can you point us to how other projects deal with this same issue?  Do
they commit both unminified and minified versions together?

Would a hash/mention of the upstream version we minified suffice?
That seems to me like a good compromise: instead of putting in the
actual sources, we can put in a text file with a url and git commit
hash of the version we actually used.  That's as good as the source
itself, and it saves us the duplication of having those unminified
sources around all the time.

some projects I found by just checking whats in debian where calibre, cardstories, couchdb and beets (http://code.google.com/p/beets/issues/detail?id=259)
As far as I can tell they have both minified and unminified sources in their tarballs.

the minified sources without original form are a reason for removal from the archive:
http://ftp-master.debian.org/REJECT-FAQ.html see generated files
A link to the used sources is not enough, I would still have to repackage your tarball to add the unminified versions.

you only have to commit the unminified sources once per release, that should be manageable.

OK, given the FAQ, I guess we have to do this.  Not happy about it though.

On Mon, Jan 16, 2012 at 1:57 PM, Julian Taylor
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> some projects I found by just checking whats in debian where calibre, cardstories, couchdb and beets (http://code.google.com/p/beets/issues/detail?id=259)
> As far as I can tell they have both minified and unminified sources in their tarballs.
> 
> the minified sources without original form are a reason for removal from the archive:
> http://ftp-master.debian.org/REJECT-FAQ.html see generated files
> A link to the used sources is not enough, I would still have to repackage your tarball to add the unminified versions.
> 
> you only have to commit the unminified sources once per release, that should be manageable.
> 
> ---
>

> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1265#issuecomment-3519065

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

On Tue, Jan 17, 2012 at 11:11 AM, Brian E. Granger
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> OK, given the FAQ, I guess we have to do this.  Not happy about it though.

Yes, I was really hoping a link/hash would suffice.  But getting
booted off pretty much every linux distro out there (since these days
so many popular ones are debian derivatives) isn't really an option...

I can help out with this, Brian.

When we are using dev branches of a project do we also need to
document somewhere what branch/head we are using?  Where should we put
that info?

On Tue, Jan 17, 2012 at 11:30 AM, Fernando Perez
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> On Tue, Jan 17, 2012 at 11:11 AM, Brian E. Granger

> wrote:

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

On Tue, Jan 17, 2012 at 11:32 AM, Brian E. Granger
reply@reply.github.com
wrote:

> Where should we put that info?

What I did when I updated CodeMirror was to put a file called
README-IPython.rst with the version info and the (tiny) diff we had
against upstream.  I think we could follow that pattern here too,
indicating the commit hash of the code we download, along with the
download URL.

What's the benefit of tracking minified sources instead of the 'real' ones?  As @juliantaylor mentioned, this isn't functionally source, it's effectively a binary.  It seems to me like we should minify as a deploy/install step, rather than the other way around.

@minrk, the point @ellisonbg makes above is that the include paths change completely, so that the css templates declaring the inclusions would need to be updated dynamically at release time.  That one does seem to be a real hassle.

If it was only the issue of running a minifyer by the release manager, I'd say that's no trouble at all.  But the point Brian brings up seems a bit more serious.

I've just realized that we continued discussing this as something we needed to act on (as @ellisonbg says above), but we never reopened the issue.  @juliantaylor brought this up today in a separate conversation with me, so I'd like to bump this up on everyone's radar.

I'm going to mark it for 0.13 so we can try to solve this once and for all.  It's causing real troubles for the distribution packagers, and they really do a lot of work that we benefit from.  Good debian packaging has a huge impact for us (many downstream distros, massive testing infrastructure applied to all packages, ...), so I want to make sure we do our best to work with them.

As per the FAQ above, we're basically risking getting kicked out of debian, and that's not an outcome we want.

there is currently no risk that it will be kicked out of debian, the blobs are removed from the package and instead use the packaged jquery.

I just do not see the issue in having the source in your git (or via a submodule)
git packs are compressed, so minified or unminified is only a few kb difference.
Also that -ui are many files instead of one large one is just cosmetic, there are already more that 600 files in the source, what does it matter if there are 36 more in a subfolder?

> Also that -ui are many files instead of one large one is just cosmetic

That is simply false. Splitting files into multiple requests, and increasing the size of the requests has a real effect on the network traffic.

how is that related to the source?
I don't care what the default installs, as long as what installs it can be generated from the source to, even when it requires manual work (cat *js | yui-compressor > out.js)

I never requested that you install the unminified sources or all of the seperate ui files. You can keep installing the minified one (which can be in the source too)
I just want the source so I can mangle them myself because I don't trust your blobs.

Ah, so you want us to add minification dependencies which few people have to the build process?  The different url pattern means this makes running from the source dir and running from an install totally different.

With the current state of the unminified readme, you have no reason to trust our blobs.  Just discard them and create them yourself, as described there.

no, I just want the source, no more.
If you add some minification process to your build is up to you, I don't care.
Again: minified stuff in the source is fine, as long as the original source is available too.
So you can keep just installing the pregenerated minified version.

> With the current state of the unminified readme, you have no reason to trust our blobs. Just discard them and create
> them yourself, as described there.

unless you forget to update the files again, or the upstream link becomes unavailable or changes to point to something else.
This is all less problematic if you track stable releases.
But currently you don't, you track a untagged git commit.

Ah, gotcha - that seems sensible.

> This is all less problematic if you track stable releases.
> But currently you don't, you track a untagged git commit.

Indeed, we kept waiting and waiting for the ui release with menus, but if I recall, pretty close to the last minute they pulled menus and cut 1.9.  At this point we just said F-it, let's use the menus branch.  We will absolutely switch back to stable as soon as menus are in a release.

So it sounds like the stable release ones are no problem, and we don't need to do anything there.  We can ship the jquery-ui sources in the unminified dir while we are not tracking a stable release, and then dump them once there is an acceptable ui release.  How does that sound?
why dump them at all?

So are you asking for the full jquery source as well?  I'm only trying to be consistent, and it seems like there is no problem with jquery, only ui.  So once we are back to using stable ui as we are doing with jquery, we can go back to treating them the same.

at least the unminified concatenated version you get with the download would be good.
From what I can tell thats frowned upon but accepted in Debian.

prettify is also currently only available minified in 0.13, while it was unminified in 0.12.1

Right - I added prettify to 0.12.1 for you after branching.  With the exception of our use of dev jquery-ui, I see any inclusion of unminified sources as simply appeasement of silly packaging rules.  It makes no sense, otherwise. For instance, if we ship unminified jquery, it's a bit of a lie because we aren't making the minified sources ourselves, we are still trusting jquery to have done it properly.  Given that, there is no practical difference between shipping the unminified js and just shipping the version number.

[try this](https://github.com/minrk/ipython/tree/unminified)

It includes the jquery-ui sources (which in turn includes jquery), so you just have to `cd jquery-ui/build && ant minify`.  It depends on yuicompressor.

the difference is that you can still edit the source in the case that jquery closes down and deletes all their stuff from the servers or prune their git branch after deciding that they don't like the menubars after all.

instead of adding the whole source you could also just add what your are using: jquery.{ui,effects}.*js and the css files
the used themes are in ipython already and one does not need all the ant stuff to do a cat *js > file

> the difference is that you can still edit the source in the case that jquery closes down and deletes all their stuff from the servers or prune their git branch after deciding that they don't like the menubars after all.

The same goes for tornado, readline, zmq, and Python itself.

As I said above, "with the exception of our use of dev jquery-ui".  I am convinced by your arguments that we should ship our jQuery-UI snapshot, at least until there is a stable release.  Once there is a stable release, the difference between shipping totally unused code and shipping a version string is nonexistent.
